0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-cheney-idUSKCN10O0DL	Liz Cheney's Wyoming campaign backed by big names
column2: bigger money	"

column1: By Ruffin Prevost
| CODY
column2: Wyo.

column1: CODY
column2: Wyo. Former Vice President Dick Cheney's eldest daughter
column3: bouncing back from an aborted 2014 U.S. Senate bid
column4: heads into a crowded primary race next week for Wyoming's lone seat in the House of Representatives buoyed by big-name Republicans and wealthy out-of-state donors.Liz Cheney
column5: the apparent Republican front-runner
column6: has commanded a level of fund-raising and A-list party support - including two former presidents and onetime Cabinet members - that is rare
column7: if not unheard of
column8: for a relative newcomer to Wyoming politics.Her strength is even more significant in a solidly red state where the Republican primary winner is virtually assured victory in the general election.""She can go to Chicago or New York
column9: and in one fund-raiser pull in more money than the next two closest candidates combined
column11: a daughter-in-law of former longtime Wyoming Republican Senator Alan Simpson and a Cody-based civic activist who backs one of Cheney's primary foes
column15: has received individual donations totaling more than $1.1 million
column16: far outpacing the collective campaign receipts of her seven Republican opponents and the two Democrats running in Wyoming's primary elections on Tuesday.According to the latest opinion poll on the race
column17: conducted during the second week of July
column18: more than half of Wyoming voters were undecided
column20: more than twice the following of her nearest competitor.Her standing marks a striking turnaround from her first bid for public office
column21: when she returned to her home state three years ago to challenge incumbent Senator Mike Enzi and was branded by some fellow Republicans as a ""carpetbagger"" backed by deep-pocketed outsiders.

column1: Her campaign also suffered from a public feud with her sister Mary Cheney
column2: a lesbian
column3: over Liz Cheney's opposition to same-sex marriage. BRAND NAMES
column4: DEEP POCKETS

column1: She ended up withdrawing from that race several months later
column2: citing a family health crisis. Cheney and her husband
column3: Phil Perry
column4: an attorney
column5: have five children.

column1: Now Cheney
column2: also a lawyer who worked in the State Department while her father was vice president
column3: is leveraging her Washington connections as she runs for the open
column4: at-large House seat in the nation's least populous state.Campaigning as a ""strong conservative voice for Wyoming
column5: she has vowed to protect the state's pivotal coal industry
column6: defend gun rights and generally work ""to reverse President Obama's devastating policies.""Among her contributors are a prominent group of her father's former high-ranking government colleagues
column7: including former Presidents George H.W. Bush and George W. Bush
column8: as well as former Secretary of State James Baker
column10: former Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Wolfowitz and former White House political adviser Karl Rove.Other prominent donors include New York Jets owner Woody Johnson
column11: Colorado oil and entertainment magnate Philip Anschutz
column14: and Chicago real estate and media investor Sam Zell.

column1: Cheney's two closest Republican primary rivals are state Representative Tim Stubson and Christensen
column2: who rank second and third
column3: respectively
column4: in fund-raising and in polls. They have raised $255
column5: 000 combined in individual donations. Cheney
column6: who was on the campaign trail and unavailable for comment
column7: has accepted no political action committee funds
column8: and PAC funding has figured little in the race.She raised the bulk of her campaign money by the end of March
column9: with nearly half of individual contributions meeting the $2
column10: 700 limit set by federal election laws. Most came from outside Wyoming.Still
column11: Cheney ""has raised more money from more Wyoming donors than any of her opponents
column13: campaign manager Bill Novotny said. ""A national effort is what it's going to take to stand up to Hillary Clinton"" at the top of the Democratic ticket in November
column14: he added. (Editing by Steve Gorman and Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-strategy-idUSKCN10N2DL	Clinton happily yields national spotlight to Trump
column2: avoids its glare	"

column1: By Amanda Becker
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON If you haven't heard a lot about what Hillary Clinton thinks of a string of controversial comments by Donald Trump that have generated round-the-clock coverage on cable news broadcasts
column2: there is a reason - it's by design.Since becoming the Democratic nominee last month
column3: Clinton has been touring toy manufacturers
column4: visiting tie makers and dropping in on public health clinics
column5: where if she mentions Trump at all
column6: it is usually to contrast their policies.Her swift condemnation at a Wednesday campaign rally of Trump's remark that gun rights activists could stop her from nominating liberal U.S. Supreme Court justices was a rare instance where she has directly engaged her Republican rival in the 2016 race for the White House.Aides say Clinton's strategy is simple: let Trump be Trump.Trump has suffered a series of missteps over the past two weeks that go beyond his remarks on gun rights activists
column7: which he later accused the media of deliberately misinterpreting.He has tangled with party leaders
column8: clashed with the parents of a fallen Muslim American Army captain and this week accused Clinton
column10: and President Barack Obama of ""founding"" the Islamic State militant group. On Friday
column11: he said he was just being sarcastic when he made that remark. ""There is an adage in politics:  Don't get in the way of a train wreck
column13: a top campaign aide to presidential candidates Al Gore in 2000 and John Kerry in 2004.Clinton's advisers say they see little benefit in her going toe-to-toe with Trump over every personal accusation
column14: generating sound bites that would dominate cable news broadcasts. Rather
column15: they are happy for him to be embroiled in controversy while Clinton focuses on policy.

column1: Trump's campaign declined to comment for this story
column2: but the New York real estate developer has accused the national media of bias toward Clinton. He re-posted a supporter's Tweet on Friday that said the ""corrupt media"" was deliberately exaggerating his remarks to favor his Democratic opponent. Trump has slipped in opinion polls
column3: and worried Republican Party leaders have urged him to stop making off-the-cuff inflammatory statements that generate blanket
column4: often negative
column5: media coverage and distract from efforts to highlight what they see as Clinton's many shortcomings.SUCKING OUT THE OXYGEN

column1: He's sucking all the oxygen out of the room to his own detriment
column2: said Republican strategist and Trump supporter Ford O'Connell. It's not enough to dominate media coverage
column3: he needs to ""win"" it
column4: O'Connell said.Trump has boasted that the news coverage he generates means he does not have to spend as much on campaign ads
column5: but political veterans say he is squandering the attention and missing opportunities to win over undecided voters.For example
column6: Trump gave an economic speech on Monday that was meant to help his campaign regain momentum
column7: but it was quickly eclipsed by the fallout over his remarks on gun rights activists.Clinton
column8: meanwhile
column9: has been busy courting local media in must-win states. Her national press pool
column10: which seldom gets to question the candidate
column11: often waits as she conducts interviews with local news outlets.

column1: She has granted few recent interviews to national outlets and rarely holds press conferences
column2: a strategy her critics say is calculated to avoid questions about her use of a private email server during her time as secretary of state
column3: and the relationship between her family's global charity
column4: the Clinton Foundation
column5: and the State Department.Clinton
column6: who has said she is one of the most transparent presidential candidates in history
column7: has acknowledged her use of the private email server was a mistake but said she properly handled all classified information. She has denied any improper links between the foundation and the State Department.In interviews with local outlets
column8: Clinton is more likely to face questions about job creation
column9: public health and raising wages - all parts of her platform that she is keen to discuss.In Florida
column11: Republican lobbyist Gus Corbella says the contrast between the local coverage of Clinton's campaign stops there and Trump's events has been stark.""Clinton's campaign seems to have the more disciplined approach
column12: Corbella said. ""The rollout that day is on a specific event she's attending
column13: a message she's trying to deliver. Whereas on the Trump side
column14: it's what crazy thing did he say today and the response to that.""After Clinton's visit last week to a tie maker in Colorado
column15: the lead story on the front page of the Denver Post was ""Clinton pledges millions of jobs."" Trump also featured on the front page
column16: but in a smaller story about ""damage control"" in his troubled campaign. (Reporting by Amanda Becker; Additional reporting by Michelle Conlin in New York and James Oliphant in Washington

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-california-emissions-vehicles-idUSKCN10N2B5	California lawmaker to float zero emissions vehicle bill	"
By Rory Carroll
| SAN FRANCISCO
SAN FRANCISCO A California lawmaker next week will introduce a bill requiring 15 percent of all vehicles sold in the state to be emissions-free by 2025
column2: her spokeswoman said on Friday.Assemblywoman Autumn Burke says the legislation is needed to ensure that California's current zero emissions vehicle target is met with actual vehicles and not just clean car credits
column3: which environmentalists claim have flooded the market. ""Governor (Jerry) Brown has set an ambitious goal of 1.5 million electric vehicles by 2025
column4: but unless we take action
column5: the state won't come close to meeting this goal
column6: said Burke
column7: who represents the city of Inglewood in car-centric Los Angeles county. ""That's why we need to reform the rules to require that 15 percent of all cars sold in California have zero emissions by 2025. This is about clean cars
column8: not credits
column9: she said in a statement to Reuters.

column1: The bill will require the California Air Resources Board to adopt a regulation by the end of next year to reach the 15 percent goal. CARB has for years operated a zero emission vehicles program
column2: which has helped the state achieve its current level of about 200
column3: 000 ZEVs on the road.

column1: But a complex system of clean car credits
column2: designed to give automakers flexibility in meeting the sales target
column3: has led to a glut of credits
column4: according to experts. Environmental groups like the Natural Resources Defense Council and electric car manufacturer Tesla Motors told CARB at a recent meeting that auto companies may be able to reach the state's target by simply submitting credits
column5: and said changes to the program's credit system are required.

column1: About 4 percent of vehicles sold in California are zero emissions vehicles
column2: which include full battery electric
column3: hydrogen fuel cell
column4: and plug-in hybrids. The NRDC estimates that under the current rules and credit system
column5: California would  have only 6 percent of all vehicles emission-free by 2025.   (Reporting by Rory Carroll; Editing by Jonathan Oatis and Dan Grebler)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKCN10N240	Clinton leads Trump by five points in White House race: Reuters/Ipsos	"
By Maurice Tamman
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Democrat Hillary Clinton led Republican Donald Trump by more than 5 percentage points in the Reuters/Ipsos tracking poll released on Friday
column2: little changed in weeks as the U.S. presidential campaign wobbles into the heart of summer.Since July 28
column3: Clinton's daily support among likely voters in the poll has hovered between a low of 41 and a high of 44 percentage points. She was at 41 percentage points on Thursday
column4: down slightly this week.Trump's support has moved slightly more
column5: ranging from a low of 33 percentage points to a high of 39 points. He was at 36 points on Thursday
column6: up slightly this week.Among registered voters
column7: Clinton was ahead by 9 points on Thursday

column1: At this point in the 2012 election
column2: both President Barack Obama and Republican nominee Mitt Romney had solidified their support
column3: and Romney held a 45 percent to 41 percent lead
column4: with only 14 percent of likely voters not picking one of the two candidates.Trump
column5: a New York businessman seeking his first elected office
column6: has been mired in controversies in recent days
column7: and many establishment Republicans have begun to distance themselves from his campaign.He drew heavy criticism for suggesting gun rights activists could take action against Clinton
column8: a statement he later said was meant to rally votes against her. On Thursday he repeatedly accused Clinton and Obama of being co-founders of the Islamic State militant group. On Friday he said the remarks were meant to be sarcasm.

column1: On Thursday
column2: the number of likely voters who were not picking either Clinton or Trump in the Nov. 8 presidential election was 22 percent. That number has remained stubbornly in the 20- to 25-point range for weeks.Despite that
column3: neither of the alternative candidates is gaining traction. In a four-way race
column4: Libertarian Gary Johnson saw his support dip slightly to 7 percentage points on Thursday
column5: down from a high of nearly 9 points earlier this week.

column1: Green Party nominee Jill Stein was at about 3 points on Thursday
column2: largely unchanged.The results on Thursday were taken from a sample of 1
column3: 446 registered voters and 1
column4: 116 likely voters surveyed between Aug. 7 and Aug. 11. The results have a credibility interval of plus or minus 3 percentage points. (Editing by Jonathan Oatis and Howard Goller)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-democrats-hack-idUSKCN10N00D	Exclusive: Congressional leaders were briefed a year ago on hacking of Democrats - sources	"
By Mark Hosenball and John Walcott
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. intelligence officials told top congressional leaders a year ago that Russian hackers were attacking the Democratic Party
column2: three sources familiar with the matter said on Thursday
column3: but the lawmakers were unable to tell the targets about the hacking because the information was so secret.The disclosure of the Top Secret information would have revealed that U.S. intelligence agencies were continuing to monitor the hacking
column4: as well as the sensitive intelligence sources and the methods they were using to do it.The material was marked with additional restrictions and assigned a unique codeword
column5: limiting access to a small number of officials who needed to know that U.S. spy agencies had concluded that two Russian intelligence agencies or their proxies were targeting the Democratic National Committee
column6: the central organizing body of the Democratic Party.The National Security Agency and other intelligence agencies sometimes delay informing targets of foreign intelligence activities under similar circumstances
column7: officials have said.The alleged hacking of the Democrats and the Russian connection did not become public until late last month when the FBI said it was investigating a cyber attack at the DNC. The DNC did not respond to a request for comment for this story.The congressional briefing was given last summer in a secure room called a Sensitive Compartmented Information Facility
column8: or SCIF
column9: to a group of congressional leaders informally known as the ""Gang of Eight
column10: the sources said.The group at the time included four Republicans: Senate Majority leader Mitch McConnell and House of Representatives Speaker John Boehner
column11: and Senator Richard Burr and Representative Devin Nunes
column12: the House and Senate intelligence committee chairs. Their Democratic counterparts were: Senator Harry Reid and Representative Nancy Pelosi
column13: and Senator Dianne Feinstein and Representative Adam Schiff of the intelligence committees.

column1: AshLee Strong
column2: press secretary for the current House Speaker
column3: Paul Ryan
column4: declined to comment
column5: and Pelosi's office did not immediately respond to requests for comment.Pelosi on Thursday called the hacking an ""electronic Watergate"" and said the Russians were behind it.""SPEARPHISHING""

column1: DNC officials have said they did not learn about the hacking until months after the initial congressional briefing
column2: when an agent from an FBI cybersecurity squad asked them last fall about the party's data security arrangements.

column1: Even then
column2: the Democratic sources said
column3: the FBI agent never mentioned that U.S. intelligence officials suspected that Russian hackers were targeting the organization.The attack on the DNC later led the hackers to other party organizations
column4: including the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee
column5: which raises funds for House candidates
column6: Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign
column7: and other groups.A DCCC spokeswoman declined to comment.

column1: The hackers initially used ""spearphishing"" - attacks on the private email accounts of dozens of people working for the organizations
column2: several sources said.One of the sources said the Clinton campaign first detected attacks on its data system in early March
column3: and was given what the source described as a ""general briefing"" about it by the FBI later that month. The source said the FBI made no mention of a Russian connection in that briefing and did not say when the penetration first took place. According to a memo obtained by Reuters
column4: interim DNC Chair Donna Brazile said on Thursday she was creating a Cybersecurity Advisory Board ""to ensure prevent future attacks and ensure that the DNC's cybersecurity capabilities are best-in-class.""(This version of the story corrects seventh paragraph to show that John Boehner was House speaker at time of briefing) (Reporting by Mark Hosenball and John Walcott; Additional reporting by Julia Harte; Editing by Ross Colvin)"

| WARREN

column1: WARREN
column2: Mich. U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton on Thursday said rival Donald Trump had no real plans to help middle-class families
column3: arguing that his agenda of tax cuts and tough trade talk would throw the economy into recession.""He's offered no credible plans to address what working families are up against today
column4: Clinton said in Warren
column5: Michigan
column6: shortly after touring Futuramic
column7: a hangar-like
column8: high-tech factory that makes parts for the aerospace industry.Clinton said Trump

column13: an inheritance tax that generally hits the wealthy.Clinton offered no new proposals of her own but sought to cast doubt on the image Trump promotes of himself as the voice for working people. The New York businessman is counting on his appeal to blue-collar voters with concerns about global trade to boost his chances in key states such as Pennsylvania and Ohio.

column1: Clinton on Thursday ran through many of the policies she has outlined over the last year to contrast herself with Trump
column2: who has given far fewer details about his plans

column6: including the Trans-Pacific Partnership."" (Additional reporting by Emily Stephenson and Amanda Becker in Washington; Editing by Leslie Adler)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-ukraine-idUSKCN10M2MH	Trump adviser joined key party meeting on Ukraine	"
By Mark Hosenball
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON A foreign policy adviser to U.S. presidential candidate Donald Trump confirmed his attendance at a meeting last month during which the Republican Party agreed to watered-down language in its support of Ukraine.J. D. Gordon
column2: the adviser who previously served as a Pentagon spokesman

Gordon called Denman's version of events ""inaccurate."" Stephen Yates
column8: co-chair of the national security subcommittee
column9: confirmed that Trump campaign members were present at the meeting where Ukraine language for the RNC platform was discussed. But he said only delegates participated in the debate and denied the Trump campaign played any role in softening the Ukraine language.

column1: The details of the meeting in Cleveland have attracted scrutiny and raised questions about the Trump campaign's stance toward Russia.Trump has said he would seek to build a closer relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin
column2: praising him as a stronger leader than U.S. President Barack Obama. In the last month
column3: Trump has also suggested he might not defend NATO allies if they did not spend more on defense
column4: appeared to invite Russia to hack the emails of Democratic opponent Hillary Clinton and suggested he might accept Russia's 2014 annexation of Crimea from Ukraine.

column1: Denman
column2: a member of the platform committee's national security subcommittee
column3: said she proposed language that supported ""providing lethal defensive weapons to Ukraine's armed forces and greater coordination with NATO on defense planning."" That phrase was eventually changed to remove the reference to ""lethal defensive weapons.""In the end
column4: the platform
column5: which serves as a largely symbolic statement of the party's priorities
column6: criticizes the Obama administration for encouraging a ""resurgent Russia"" and supports continued sanctions on Moscow and ""appropriate assistance to the armed forces of the Ukraine"" without specifying what that would involve.Yates said Denman could have reintroduced the amendment in the full committee meeting if she felt strong-armed in subcommittee. ""I don't have particular sympathy for delegates who chose not to avail themselves of the opportunity in full committee
column7: and then start spinning yarn about how this came about
column8: he said.

column1: Denman said she stands by her account.Russia on Thursday announced it would conduct war games in the Black Sea
column2: a day after Putin accused Ukraine of trying to provoke a conflict over Crimea. (Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"
